results.title: Earthquakes: lesson of a disaster
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth science series”.
Documents the social and physical aftermath of two earthquakes, a major one in Turkey and a smaller one in California. The film shows the effects of both earthquakes on buildings and the surrounding landscape. The problems of how to cope with such a disaster are also shown. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Living with earth: the Loma Prieta Earthquake
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 25 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Examines human responses to the destructive forces of natural phenomena such as earthquakes. In particular, the San Francisco quake of 1989 is highlighted. Geologists, scientists, engineers and civic planners studied the earthquake and its effects to determine how to better manage a crisis situation given that San Francisco rests on the San Andreas fault line. Although earthquake predicting technology is in its early protype stages, the aim of developing this area will be beneficial in lessening the impact of one natural disaster.

results.title: Mountain building
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Mountains are evidence which enable geologists to study not only the movements of the Earth’s plates, but the composition of the interior structure of the Mantle. The Rock cycle whereby material from and below the crust is metamorphosed is also explained which enables geologists to determined how land masses are created and fused together into larger parts, eventually becoming mountain ranges. Fossil evidence and magnetic forces enable the geologist to determine the age and structure of terrain.

results.title: The Sea floor
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Earth revealed”.
The sea-floor is the focus of submarine geologists. Water covers 70% of the planet’s surface and contains many of tye minerals and elements which sustain life itself. The sea-floor is largely basaltic, while continental landmasses are largely granitic. Like the landmass on the planet surface, the sea-floor has a volcanic structure, which gives rise to its varying seascapes mid-oceanic ridges, ocean trenches and fracture zones. The use of deep sea robots have enabled submarine geologists to understand how old the sea floor is.

results.title: The Restless planet
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Earth revealed”.
The creation of the planets in our solar system has had an enormous impact on the geological structure of the Earth,and the existence of life on the planet. This episode examines the origins of the solar system and planets, and how the Earth and its atmosphere evolved. The Earth and its inter-relationship with the planets is also examined.

results.title: Down to earth
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Earth revealed”.
This episode introduces the vast field of geology and the work undertaken by scientists in that and other related fields. Excellent visuals stimulate the viewer’s appreciation of the Earth and a broad overview is provided on Plate Tectonics, earthquakes, seismology and the origins of our planet.

results.title: The Birth of a theory
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Addresses some controversial geological theories including the theories of Continental Drift and Plate Tectonics. It was only in the middle of the 20th Century that scientists accepted that the major continents were once joined and then drifted apart due to the geological activity occuring on and beneath the Earth’s surface. The study of the ocean floor provided valuable evidence which enabled the theory to eventually gain popular support.

results.title: Metamorphic rocks
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 18 of Series “Earth revealed”.
The process of metamorphism changes the structure and composition of rocks; an atomic shuffling which results in change. Metamorphism for example is responsible for changing limestone into marble. There are two types of metamorphism; contact metamorphism resulting from a cooling process and regional metamorphism which is the result of tectonic activity. As a consequence of this process, many rare minerals can be formed.

results.title: Mass wasting
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 16 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Mass wasting is the continual chain of processes that move earth, rocks and debris from the top of landmasses to the bottom. Tectonic activity and gravity assist the process which can result in gradual creeps and slumps to more damaging landslides and avalanches. The effects of mass wasting are important to geologists as they assist engineers in the design and construction of structures on potentially unstable landforms.

results.title: Weathering & soils
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Weathering of the earth’s surface is important to geologists as they examine the impact of this process. There are two types: mechanical and chemical weathering. Mechanical weathering involves the disintegration and break-up of fragments of rock at the earth’s surface naturally. The composition of the rock doesn’t change at all. In chemical weathering, water and air decompose the rock and change its composition such as iron ore can become oxidised into rust in the presence of water. Acid raid formation is affected by the chemical weathering of the earth’s surface as is soil composition and productivity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
